Modern_Republic

I took it last week. I thought the multiple choice portion was pretty easy. The DBQ wasn't too bad, although I didn't know too much about how the Revolution effected the early womens' rights movement.
 
 So who else took it? What did you think?

post_info.post_title: Who Took The AP US History Test This Year?

sanguinekane

I took it. I'm the only senior in my whole school taking AP History. :) 
 
 Anyway, I thought it wasn't that bad. The DBQ was a lot easier than I thought it would be. The one snag however was one of the multiple-choice essay questions. I think it might have been the first one. I simply couldnt come up with an essay for either prompt, so instead I wrote my own about how I really gain no benefit from taking this test (I get the scores way to late to report them to my college, and I don't want to skip any history classes anyway), and that I should be back in bed. 
 
 Will my grade suffer horribly because of that? Probably, unless I get a grader with a sense of humor. emoticon_rolleyes
Duo_Maxwell

as I recall, graders take about 30 seconds to a minute to grade each paper. I know a guy who goes every year to the middle of nowhere to grade the AP european history test and then takes what he finds and teaches it to his AP euro students. 
 
 As long as you throw jargon and key terms while making some decent amount of sense, you should do fine. They aren't reading carefully at all.
Modern_Republic

I took it. I'm the only senior in my whole school taking AP History. :) 
 
 Anyway, I thought it wasn't that bad. The DBQ was a lot easier than I thought it would be. The one snag however was one of the multiple-choice essay questions. I think it might have been the first one. I simply couldnt come up with an essay for either prompt, so instead I wrote my own about how I really gain no benefit from taking this test (I get the scores way to late to report them to my college, and I don't want to skip any history classes anyway), and that I should be back in bed. 
 
 Will my grade suffer horribly because of that? Probably, unless I get a grader with a sense of humor. emoticon_rolleyes

 
 So I take it your testing was mandatory? If so, the same is true for my school. It would be pretty redundant to take the test as a senior. When the AP tests here were made mandatory, seniors were known to have taken their tests in spanish. I think it's pretty funny myself, but the district definitely does not--- each test costs $85.
 
 Here are the multiple choice essay topics I remember.
 
 Evaluate the economy of the Mass. Bay Colony with that of.. somewhere else that I don't remember.. (I didn't choose that one)
 
 Evaluate the sectional perspectives (North, South, West) of the Mexican-American War and the resulting debate. (I chose this one.. unfortunately I forgot the name of 'The Wilmot Proviso.. so I just referred to it as legislation demanding that the Mexican cessions not be made into slave territory.. I hope my grader doesn't mind)
 
 I think those were the two essay options from the 1st question.
 
 I only remember one of the questions from the second series which went something like this:
 
 Discuss the social impact of the following:
 Choose two of the three
 
 Civil rights movement
 Antiwar movement
 .. and I can't remember the last one.. probably because I didn't do it.
 
 One of the things that I was surprised by was how little the time restriction effected my testing. I was done with the writing portion with about 15 minutes remaining.
 
 The result really won't have much of an impact on myself.. it will probably just be an issue of pride. I also have this theory that with very strong AP test results, schools won't even consider your GPA (not that I have a bad one, I have a 3.88.. but my class rank probably isn't too strong considering my public school is 'one of the best' in the country).
 
 Duo, have you taken the AP Euro or AP Government tests? If so, how hard were they? I'm taking those classes next year.
sanguinekane

Oh no, testing wasn't mandatory, it's simply encouraged, and because my AP history teacher wrote one of my recomendation letters when I was applying to schools (not that I really needed them, as my top three choices where all universities that didn't take recomendations), I gave in to the pressure.
Modern_Republic
How many of the 85 multiple choice questions do you think you need to answer correctly in order to earn a 5 for that portion of the test?
Duo_Maxwell
isn't the AP US test run around a 65-70 for 5? it's much higher then the Ap physics and calc tests for sure which run typically 45-50%.
Modern_Republic

isn't the AP US test run around a 65-70 for 5? it's much higher then the Ap physics and calc tests for sure which run typically 45-50%.

 
 Wow. That's easy as hell. If I missed 5 questions I would be surprised. So, it all comes down to the written portion.
 
 Supposedly AP Physics is impossibly hard.
Duo_Maxwell

Wow. That's easy as hell. If I missed 5 questions I would be surprised. So, it all comes down to the written portion.

 
 Ap tests really aren't that hard for the most part. 
 
 

 Supposedly AP Physics is impossibly hard.

 
 Calc and physics are insane. I went to one of the best private highschools in the US, and my friends who were taking the physics C and BC calc were like "yeah, i got 1/2 right on the AP practice test, i should be fine." That completely blew my mind.
notdakuningist

Out of the tests I took I scored a 4 in history and English and 3's in bio, government and finally recieved a 2 in latin. The biggest problem I had with them was actually the cost of taking the four of them, it sucked not getting a refund on the latin though. 
 As far as the history test went most of the dbq's were pretty easy, with the essays being only a little difficult. As far as the grading thing goes however though they don't spend alot of time on each test, they do know what to look for in a response so don't skim on the details. Just make sure that if you use dates that they are correct (if you can't remember don't bring it up) and that you write about the prompt without going off topic.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Who Took The AP US History Test This Year?
